questions.text: After a long stressful day, what would make you feel most loved?

options.text: Your partner sits with you, phones away, and asks about your day
Your partner says 'I'm so proud of how you handled that. You're amazing'
Your partner pulls you into a long, tight hug without saying anything
Your partner has already made dinner and cleaned up so you can relax
Your partner surprises you with your favorite treat they picked up

questions.text: When you want to show someone you care about them, your instinct is to:

options.text: Tell them specifically what you appreciate about them
Clear your schedule to spend uninterrupted time together
Do something helpful for them without being asked
Give them a hug, hold their hand, or touch their shoulder
Buy or make them something meaningful

questions.text: Your partner is overwhelmed with work. What would you naturally do?

options.text: Take over their household tasks so they can focus
Send encouraging texts throughout the day
Order their favorite meal to be delivered
Sit with them while they work, just being present
Give them a shoulder massage while they work

questions.text: What bothers you most when you're feeling disconnected from your partner?

options.text: When they're physically present but mentally elsewhere (on their phone, distracted)
When they rarely say 'I love you' or compliment you
When they don't help out even though you're clearly overwhelmed
When they pull away or avoid physical affection
When they forget special occasions or never bring you anything

questions.text: A friend is going through a breakup. How do you support them?

options.text: Show up with comfort food or a care package
Call them and say 'You're going to get through this. You're stronger than you know'
Clear your weekend to be with them, doing whatever they need
Help them with practical stuff - moving belongings, changing locks, etc.
Just sit with them and let them cry on your shoulder

questions.text: What makes you feel most secure in a relationship?

options.text: Regular verbal reassurance that they love and value you
Consistent quality time together, even if it's just mundane activities
When they do little things to make your life easier without asking
Frequent physical affection throughout the day
Thoughtful gestures that show they're thinking about you

questions.text: Your partner accomplished something significant. How do you celebrate with them?

options.text: Write them a heartfelt note about why you're proud of them
Plan a special date or experience to celebrate together
Buy them a gift that commemorates their achievement
Take care of everything at home so they can fully enjoy the moment
Give them a huge hug and hold them close

questions.text: Which situation would hurt your feelings most?

options.text: They criticize you or say harsh things during an argument
They repeatedly cancel plans you were looking forward to
They never help around the house even when you're exhausted
They flinch or pull away when you try to be affectionate
They show up empty-handed to your birthday

questions.text: You notice your partner seems down. What's your first instinct?

options.text: Ask them to talk about it and really listen
Tell them 'I'm here for you. You're not alone in this'
Handle their responsibilities so they have space to process
Hold them or rub their back
Bring them something to cheer them up

questions.text: What do you cherish most about a good relationship?

options.text: Hearing 'I love you' and knowing they mean it
Having adventures and making memories together
Having a partner who lightens your load in life
The comfort of physical closeness
The thoughtfulness behind meaningful surprises

questions.text: When apologizing to someone you hurt, you're most likely to:

options.text: Give a sincere verbal apology explaining what you'll do differently
Ask if you can spend time talking through what happened
Do something concrete to make amends or fix the problem
Offer a hug or comforting touch (if appropriate)
Bring them something as a peace offering

questions.text: You're going through a difficult time. What would help you feel most supported?

options.text: Someone saying 'You're doing your best. I believe in you'
Having someone sit with you without needing to fix anything
Someone handling tasks you're too overwhelmed to do
A long hug or someone holding your hand
A thoughtful gift that shows they understand what you're going through

questions.text: It's your partner's birthday. How do you make them feel special?

options.text: Find or create the perfect meaningful gift
Write them a letter expressing what they mean to you
Plan an entire day doing their favorite activities together
Handle all the chores and responsibilities so they can relax
Give them extra physical affection throughout the day

questions.text: In a relationship, you feel most disconnected when:

options.text: There's no affectionate touch - no hand-holding, kissing, or cuddling
You're only communicating about logistics, never deeper conversations
They never acknowledge your efforts or say appreciative things
You're doing everything while they don't contribute
They never think to bring you anything or surprise you

questions.text: A colleague helped you with a big project. How do you thank them?

options.text: Send them a genuine message about how much you appreciate them
Invite them to lunch or coffee to properly thank them
Offer to help them with their next project
Give them a warm handshake or appropriate hug
Get them a thank-you gift

questions.text: What makes you feel most valued by your partner?

options.text: When they tell you specific things they admire about you
When they prioritize time with you over other things
When they notice what needs doing and just do it
When they initiate physical affection spontaneously
When they see something and think 'they would love this'

questions.text: Your partner mentions they're craving a specific food. What do you do?

options.text: Surprise them by bringing it home
Suggest you go get it together and make an outing of it
Offer to cook it for them
Text them 'I love how you know exactly what you want'
Playfully feed them a bite when you have it together

questions.text: Which scenario would make you feel most loved on a random Tuesday?

options.text: Getting a text: 'Just thinking about you. You make my life better'
Your partner suggesting a spontaneous walk together
Coming home to find they already took care of the thing you were dreading
Your partner pulling you close while you're cooking dinner
Finding a small surprise they picked up 'just because'

questions.text: Someone in your life seems stressed. Your natural response is to:

options.text: Remind them of their strengths and that they can handle this
Offer to help them work through it together
Ask what's on their plate and take something off it
Give them a comforting touch on the shoulder or arm
Bring them their favorite coffee or treat

questions.text: What matters most to you in daily life with a partner?

options.text: Hearing 'good morning,' 'I love you,' and 'goodnight' regularly
Having rituals together - morning coffee, evening walks, weekend routines
Sharing the mental load and household responsibilities
Casual touch throughout the day - passing by, sitting together, etc.
Occasional small thoughtful surprises

questions.text: You want to cheer someone up. What feels most natural?

options.text: Call them and have a real conversation
Send them an encouraging message about why they're awesome
Show up and help them with whatever they're dealing with
Give them a big hug when you see them
Drop off something that will make them smile

questions.text: You feel most loved when your partner:

options.text: Expresses gratitude for who you are, not just what you do
Turns off distractions to be fully present with you
Does the hard or annoying tasks without being asked
Reaches for your hand in public
Remembers something you mentioned and surprises you with it

questions.text: Your friend is moving to a new apartment. How do you help?

options.text: Show up with your muscles and help them move
Tell them 'This is exciting! You're going to love this new chapter'
Spend the whole day with them making it fun
Bring them a housewarming gift
Give them a celebratory hug when everything's moved in

questions.text: What would make you feel most appreciated after doing something thoughtful?

options.text: Hearing them say 'Thank you so much. That really meant a lot to me'
Having them want to spend more time with you because of it
Them doing something thoughtful for you in return
Getting an appreciative hug or kiss
Receiving a thank-you gift or gesture

questions.text: When you miss someone, what do you do?

options.text: Text or call to tell them you're thinking about them
Make plans to see them soon
Do something helpful for them remotely
Plan to greet them with a big hug next time you see them
Send them something or save something for them

questions.text: In an argument, what helps you feel like things will be okay?

options.text: Hearing 'I'm sorry' and understanding what went wrong
Sitting down together to really talk it through
Seeing them take action to fix the issue
Physical reassurance - a hug or holding hands
A peace offering or gesture of reconciliation

questions.text: You want to show long-term commitment to your partner. You'd most likely:

options.text: Give them something symbolic of your commitment
Tell them about your future together and your commitment to them
Make concrete plans for your shared future
Take on more responsibilities to build your life together
Increase physical intimacy and affection

questions.text: Which absence bothers you most in a relationship?

options.text: Never hearing words of love, appreciation, or encouragement
Never having meaningful conversations or shared experiences
Carrying all the weight while they coast
Living like roommates with no physical affection
Never receiving anything thoughtful or personal

questions.text: When you see someone you love after being apart, your first instinct is to:

options.text: Tell them how much you missed them
Ask about their time away and really listen
Take their bags or help them get settled
Hug or kiss them immediately
Have something waiting for them as a welcome

questions.text: What makes you feel most deeply connected to your partner?

options.text: When they verbalize their love and what you mean to them
When you share experiences that create memories together
When they anticipate your needs and meet them
When you're physically close - cuddling, intimate moments, sustained touch
When they give you something that shows they truly know you
